On Wednesday 17 September 2003 14:34, Alex Jacobson wrote:
> Tyler,
>
> I just looked at your slides and have some questions:

Great.

You should also view the video. I tried to make the slides as
informative as possible, but there's only so much you can do with
slides.

> You say a web service is a command interface for "pushing" commands.
> I think it more accurate to say it is an interface for "pushing" state.

Could you clarify, perhaps with an example?

> Moreover, the lambda calculus is theoretically incompatible with state
> change, requiring Monads as a separate path to describe state change --

Certainly Church's lambda-calculus did not have state change, but
many of the languages based on the lambda-calculus have
incorporated side-effects. When the presentation uses the term
lambda, it is using the term in much the same way as it is used in
Lisp.  Each node in the graph is a closure. The HTTP POST verb is
then understood to mean "apply".

Also note that the web-calculus is just an interface model, not a
computation model. The model used on the server to represent state
change is not relevant to the web-calculus. The web-calculus is
solely concerned with the interface the server exposes to the
client, just as REST is. Given this limitation, we are only
concerned with the interface aspects of the lambda-calculus,
namely applying arguments to an anonymous closure. In HTTP terms,
POSTing to a resource identified only by a URL.

As further explained in the presentation, the web-calculus then
extends the lambda-calculus model by incorporating graph
introspection, or GET in HTTP terms.

> Perhaps I am not understanding Web Calculus, but, based on this
> presentation, it strikes me as inconsistent with ReST, MoST, and the lambda
> calculus.  Perhaps you can clarify.

I suggest viewing the video. I am working on a paper based on the
video, but it is not ready yet. Of course, there is also the
web-calculus specification itself. See:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/Calculus/

In the presentation, I show how the web-calculus is defined,
starting from REST's constraints. Definition of the web-calculus
proceeds by adding constraints. This process yields a model that
is compatible with REST, as the end product necessarily conforms
to REST's constraints.

The HP presentation is at:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/HP2003/

> -Alex-
>
> PS I am in the bay area for the next week.  I'd love to meet up for coffee
> and talk about this stuff in person if you have the time.

A face-to-face meeting would be great, but unfortunately I am not
in the Bay Area anymore. I was just down visiting friends when
Mark Miller and Alan Karp arranged for the presentation at HP
Labs. Mark introduces me at the start of the presentation video.
You may know Mark from his work on the E language
<http://www.erights.org/> and Xanadu, a precursor of the WWW.

Tyler
